annotation.TEXT: For the second fortress stage, we now have to contend with Krack Shot Krock harassing us through-out most of the level (and for the record: the target doesn't actually have a name, but I couldn't resist jumping on the bandwagon after several others compared it to that one level in DKC3).

The first fortress boss doesn't really have a true weakness. Beat is pretty effective during this fight so long as you keep his laser spamming in-check (though if you have the Energy Balancer, you won't need to worry about running out of ammo for him). Leaf Boomerang also deals a bit more damage than most of the other weapons, so that also gives you another option if you don't feel like chipping away at this thing with the buster.
Almost every fortress stage has at least one new enemy type. For the first level, we have the Tri-Mines. If you get too close or shoot them, they'll produce three explosions that move towards you.

An important note here: All of the fortress stages were done in separate takes. This is mostly because your ammo is replenished if you load from a save on a fortress stage (that, and the recording curse always seems to hit me the hardest when I go for multiple fortress levels in the same take).

If you slide through that opening to the left, it actually leads to a secret room with a few goodies (bolts, an E-Tank, etc). Looking back on this, I probably should have went for it, seeing as I want my bolt count to be above a certain number by the time I finish the last stage (the reason for this will become clear later on).

The lasers in this stage aren't instant-death. Rather, they act like the fires found in Coal Man's stage (they rapidly drain your health if you touch them). With that being said, you still really want to avoid them at all costs (especially considering the layouts of some of the rooms later on).

By comparison, the wall-mounted cannons aren't really something I'd label as a new enemy (mostly because you can't destroy them, nor do they show up in the enemy roll call at the end of the game). They're more of a stage-specific hazard.
